dt: used to express unhappiness, pity, or concern

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from {it}a{/it} ah + {it}las{/it} weary, from Latin {it}lassus{/it} {ma}{mat|lassitude|}{/ma}
shortdef: —used to express unhappiness, pity, or concern

dt: {bc}a wing or a winglike anatomic part or process {dx_def}see {dxt|process:1||4}{/dx_def}

et: borrowed from Latin {it}āla{/it} "armpit, upper arm, wing, axil" going back to {it}*akslā,{/it} going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-(i)l-eh{inf}2{/inf}-{/it} (whence also Germanic {it}*ahslō-,{/it} whence Old English {it}eaxl{/it} "shoulder," Old Frisian {it}axle, axele{/it} "shoulder, armpit," Old Saxon {it}ahsla,{/it} Old High German {it}ahsla, ahsala,{/it} Old Icelandic {it}ǫxl{/it} "shoulder"), derivative with an {it}-l-{/it} suffix from {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-{/it} "pivot around which something rotates, axle" {ma}{mat|axis|}{/ma}
shortdef: a wing or a winglike anatomic part or process
